{{Medal|Silver|2010|Lead}} {{Medal|Silver|2010|Bouldering}} {{Medal|Silver|2015|Lead}} {{Medal|Silver|2015|Bouldering}} {{Medal|Silver|2017|Lead}} |show-medals = yes }} [[File:Adam Ondra climbing Silence, 9c by PAVEL BLAZEK 1-cropped.jpg|thumb|Ondra climbing [[Silence (climb)|Silence]], {{Climbing grade|9c}}, in 2017]] [[File:Adam Ondra Imst 2009.JPG|thumb|Ondra in 2009 at [[Imst]]]] '''Adam Ondra''' (born February 5, 1993) is a Czech professional [[Rock climbing|rock climber]], specializing in [[lead climbing]] and [[bouldering]]. ''[[Rock & Ice]]'' magazine described Ondra in 2013 as a [[child prodigy|prodigy]] and the leading climber of his generation.{{cite web|url=https://rockandice.com/features/perfect-play-what-it-took-to-climb-la-dura-dura-5-15c-the-worlds-hardest-route|title=Perfect Play: What It Took to Climb La Dura Dura (5.15c) – The World's Hardest Route|website=rockandice.com|last=Bisharat|first=Andrew|date=27 November 2013|access-date=14 March 2020}} Ondra is the only male athlete to have won [[IFSC Climbing World Championships|World Championship]] titles in both disciplines in the same year (2014), and he is also the only male athlete to have won the [[IFSC Climbing World Cup|World Cup]] series in both disciplines (lead climbing in 2009, 2015 and 2019, and bouldering in 2010). Ondra started climbing at the age of 6. At age 13, he climbed his first route graded {{Climbing grade|9a}}. ''Rock & Ice'' reported that by 2011, Ondra was "[[onsight]]ing 5.14c’s by the handful", and by 2013 had "more or less repeated every hard route in the world—easily". As of November 2018, Ondra had climbed 1550 routes between grades {{Climbing grade|8a}} and {{Climbing grade|9c}}, one of which was a {{Climbing grade|9c}}, three were {{Climbing grade|9b+}}, and three were onsights of {{Climbing grade|9a}}. Ondra is the first climber to have [[Redpoint (climbing)|redpointed]] a route with a proposed grade of {{Climbing grade|9c}} (''[[Silence (climb)|Silence]]'', September 3, 2017), the first climber to have redpointed a route with a proposed grade of {{Climbing grade|9b+}} (''Change'', October 4, 2012), the first to [[flash (climbing)|flash]] a {{Climbing grade|9a+}} route (''Supercrackinette'', February 10, 2018), and the second to onsight a {{Climbing grade|9a}} route (''Cabane au Canada'', July 9, 2013). According to ''[[The Economist]],'' Ondra is "regarded as possibly the best climber ever to fondle rock".{{cite news|title=Climbing without ropes: A series of remarkable feats increases the appeal of a niche sport|url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21723152-series-remarkable-feats-increases-appeal-niche-sport-climbing-without-ropes|access-date=June 9, 2017|work=[[The Economist]]|date=June 8, 2017}} == Biography == [[File:Adam Ondra Imst.JPG|thumb|200px|Adam Ondra at the IFSC Lead Worldcup Imst 2009]] Ondra started climbing at the age of six; his parents are climbers and they shared their passion with him. In 1999 (at age six) in [[Rovinj]], Croatia, Ondra easily climbed a {{Climbing grade|6a}} route with bolts every half meter. Soon he became famous in climbing magazines, as his achievements quickly grew more and more notable: * In 2001 (at age eight) he onsighted {{Climbing grade|7b+}} routes. * In 2002 (at age nine) he onsighted {{Climbing grade|7c+}} and redpointed {{Climbing grade|8a}}. * In 2003 (at age ten) he onsighted {{Climbing grade|8a}}. * In 2004 (at age eleven) he onsighted {{Climbing grade|8a+}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.czechclimbing.com/clanky.php?xtem=&key=3080|title=Adam Ondra - 11 year kid 8a+ onsight|work=Czech Climbing|date=15 May 2004|access-date=7 October 2012}} and redpointed {{Climbing grade|8c}}. * In 2005 (at age twelve) he onsighted {{Climbing grade|8b}}. * In 2006 (at age thirteen) he managed to redpoint his first {{Climbing grade|9a}}, ''Martin Krpan'' at [[Misja Pec]]. In 2007 and 2008 he won the [[IFSC Climbing World Youth Championships|IFSC World Youth Championship]], category Youth B. In 2009, at age sixteen, Ondra competed for the first time in the [[Lead Climbing World Cup]], winning ahead of Spanish [[Patxi Usobiaga]] and Japanese [[Sachi Amma]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=37090|title=Climbing World Cup Lead 2009 won by Johanna Ernst and Adam Ondra|work=PlanetMountain.com|date=16 November 2009|access-date=7 October 2012}} In 2010, he won the [[Bouldering World Cup]], ahead of Austrian [[Kilian Fischhuber]] and Japanese Tsukuru Hori, becoming the first athlete in history to win the World Cup in both disciplines (lead and bouldering).{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/ondra_noguchi_win_2010_bouldering_world_cup/ |title=Ondra, Noguchi Win 2010 Bouldering World Cup |work=Climbing |author=Genna Ord |date=2 August 2010 |access-date=7 October 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327042441/http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/ondra_noguchi_win_2010_bouldering_world_cup/ |archive-date=27 March 2012 }} In March 2011, during a trip to Spain, Ondra became the second person ever to have onsighted {{Climbing grade|8c+}} after Patxi Usobiaga. In only a few days he onsighted five {{Climbing grade|8c+}} routes, including two on the same day).{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/a_new_level_ondra_onsights_five_514cs/ |title=A New Level: Ondra Onsights Five 5.14c's |work=Climbing |author=Amanda Fox |date=21 March 2011 |access-date=7 October 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723101307/http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/a_new_level_ondra_onsights_five_514cs/ |archive-date=23 July 2012 }} On October 4, 2012, Ondra redpointed ''Change'', in the Hanshelleren Cave, [[Flatanger]], Norway. It was the first route to receive a proposed grade of {{Climbing grade|9b+}}.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-5-15c-norway/|title=Adam Ondra Climbs 5.15c in Norway|work=Climbing|author=Dougald MacDonald|date=4 October 2012|access-date=7 October 2012}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.rockandice.com/news/2278-adam-ondra-does-fa-of-worlds-hardest-route |title=Adam Ondra Does FA of World's Hardest Route |work=Rock and Ice |date=4 October 2012 |access-date=7 October 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006232624/http://www.rockandice.com/news/2278-adam-ondra-does-fa-of-worlds-hardest-route |archive-date=6 October 2012 }} On October 29, 2012, Ondra flashed one of the [[Red River Gorge]]'s hardest routes, ''Southern Smoke Direct'' {{Climbing grade|9a+}}, suggesting the grade of {{Climbing grade|9a}}.{{Cite web |url=http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/adam-ondra-flashes-514d15a |title=Adam Ondra Flashes 5.14d/15a |date=29 October 2012 |access-date=30 October 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101235759/http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/adam-ondra-flashes-514d15a |archive-date=1 November 2012 |url-status=dead }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/adam-ondra-flashes-514d15a|title=Adam Ondra Flashes 5.14d/15a|work=dpmclimbing.com|access-date=13 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101235759/http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/adam-ondra-flashes-514d15a|archive-date=2012-11-01|url-status=dead}} On November 1, he onsighted ''Pure Imagination'' and ''The Golden Ticket'', both 9a, suggesting the grade of 8c+.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-onsights-two-red-river-5-14d-routes/|title=Ondra Onsights Two Red River 5.14d Routes|work=climbing.com|access-date=13 November 2012}} On February 7, 2013, Ondra sent ''[[La Dura Dura]]'', in [[Oliana]], [[Catalonia]], Spain, his second {{Climbing grade|9b+}} after ''Change''. He worked on this project with [[Chris Sharma]] and the first ascent took Ondra nine weeks of work.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-puts-down-la-dura-dura-5-15c/|title=Ondra Puts Down La Dura Dura (5.15c)|work=Climbing|access-date=7 February 2013}} On February 9, 2013, just two days after ''La Dura Dura'', Ondra succeeded in the second ascent of the {{Climbing grade|9b}} ''Fight or flight'', first climbed by Sharma in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-adds-5-15b-to-spanish-route-tally/|title=Ondra Adds 5.15b To Spanish Route Tally|work=Climbing|access-date=10 February 2013}} On July 9, 2013, Ondra realized the second {{Climbing grade|9a}} onsight in history after [[Alex Megos|Alexander Megos]], with the ascent of ''Cabane au Canada'' in Rawyl, Switzerland.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item.php?id=68197|title=La cabane au Canada, 9a, onsight by Ondra|publisher=ukclimbing.com|author=Björn Pohl|date=9 July 2013|access-date=10 July 2013}} On November 21, 2016, Ondra completed the second free ascent of ''The Dawn Wall'', a {{Climbing grade|5.14d}} multi-[[pitch (climbing)|pitch]] route at ''[[El Capitan]]'' in the [[Yosemite Valley]]. The route is widely regarded as the hardest big wall in the world. Ondra was also the first person to lead every pitch.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/adam-ondra-completes-dawn-wall/|title=Adam Ondra Completes Dawn Wall|work=Climbing|access-date=22 November 2016}} The first free ascent was completed by Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson in January 2015 after years of scouting it to determine whether it was possible. They needed 19 days to complete the route (after 5 years to learn the moves), while Ondra needed only 8 days (after 3 weeks to learn the moves). On April 23, 2017, he set a new highpoint of the Black Diamond Project in Stockholm, Sweden believed to be the hardest indoor sport route in the world. On September 3, 2017, after about 4 years of trials, Ondra climbed ''[[Silence (climb)|Silence]]'', in the Hanshelleren Cave (Flatanger, Norway). At that point, the route was unclimbed and widely considered to be the most difficult project in the world, together with ''Le blond'', a route which is still unclimbed, bolted by Chris Sharma in Oliana. ''Silence'' was the first route to receive a proposed grade of {{Climbing grade|9c}}. The route was previously known as ''Project Hard''. On February 10, 2018, Ondra realized the first flash of a confirmed 9a+ route with his ascent of ''Super Crackinette'' in Saint-Léger du Ventoux, France. The route was first climbed by Alexander Megos after 3 days of work in 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/adam-ondra-interview-after-worlds-first-9a-plus-flash-at-st-leger-in-france.html|title=Super Crackinette, 9a+, flash by Ondra|publisher=planetmountain.com|date=12 February 2018|access-date=19 July 2018}} On November 12, 2018, Ondra onsighted ''Just do it'' (Smith Rock, Oregon), a historic 8c+ route bolted by Alan Watts in 1989 and first ascended in 1992 by [[Jean-Baptiste Tribout]]. At that time, ''Just do it'' was considered the hardest route in the U.S.{{cite web |url= http://www.climbing.com/news/siegrist-completes-just-do-it-5-14c-at-smith/ |title=Siegrist Completes Just Do It (5.14c) at Smith |work=climbing.com |year=2012 |access-date=2 February 2013}} It is a long slab (140 feet, 18 bolts) with many tricky moves and small holds hardly visible from the ground. This kind of classic route is considered to be particularly difficult to onsight, by both Adam Ondra and Alan Watts.{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BqG207Hh1bT/|title=Just Do It 8c+ was just an incredible experience|author=Adam Ondra|publisher=Instagram|date=November 13, 2018|access-date=December 24, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-onsights-just-do-it-smith-rock-america-first-8c-plus.html|title=Adam Ondra onsights Just Do It at Smith Rock, America's first 8c+|editor=planetmountain.com|date=November 12, 2018|access-date=December 24, 2018}}{{cite web |title=Adam Ondra - Just Do It, 5.14c (8c+) onsight - uncut footage - vlog #10 BONUS |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6floyyDP-w |website=youtube}} As of 2019, Ondra is working towards qualifying for the [[2020 Summer Olympics]]. He failed to qualify at the [[2019 IFSC Climbing World Championships]] as he was disqualified for accidentally toeing a bolt during the lead climbing portion of the combined event.{{Cite web|url=https://www.lacrux.com/en/klettern/adam-ondra-about-his-disqualification-at-the-klm-wm-in-japan/|title=Adam Ondra about his disqualification at the World Championships in Japan {{!}} LACRUX climbing magazine|date=2019-08-20|website=LACRUX Klettermagazin|language=en|access-date=2019-10-14}} However, at the Olympic qualifying event in Toulouse later that year, he managed to secure his selection for the Olympic games{{Cite web|url=https://www.ifsc-climbing.org/index.php/component/ifsc/?view=event&WetId=8322|title=Olympic qualifying event - event page|date=2019-12-01|website=IFSC|language=en|access-date=2019-12-02}} even though he fell ill after making it through to the finals of the event. In April 2021 Ondra won gold in the bouldering discipline at the IFSC World Cup in Meiringen. This marked his 20th World Cup gold medal.https://www.ukclimbing.com/news/2021/04/ifsc_boulder_world_cup_meiringen_2021_report-72753 [[File:Boulder Worldcup Vienna 29-05-2010a semifinals068 Adam Ondra.jpg|thumb|200px|Adam Ondra at the IFSC Boulder Worldcup Vienna 2010]] == Rankings == {{See also|Best IFSC results}} === Climbing World Cup === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | Discipline ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2009 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2010 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2011 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2012 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2013 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2014 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2015 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2016 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2017 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2018 ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2019 |- | align="left" | Lead | style="background: gold;" | 1 | style="background: #cc9966;" | 3 | 57 | - | 11 | style="background: #cc9966;" | 3 | style="background: gold;" | 1 | 23 | 27 | 31 | style="background: gold;" | 1 |- | align="left" | Bouldering | 15 | style="background: gold;" | 1 | - | - | - | 24 | style="background: #cc9966;" | 3 | - | - | - | style="background: silver;" | 2 |- | align="left" | Speed | - | - | - | - | - | - | - | - | - | - | |- | align="left" | Combined | style="background: gold;" | 1 | style="background: gold;" | 1 | - | - | - | style="background: silver;" | 2 | style="background: gold;" | 1 | - | 65 | - | style="background: silver;" | 2 |} === Climbing World Championships === '''Youth''' {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | Discipline ! style="background: #b0e0e6;" | 2007
